nodes.text: Conservation of money in transactions and statistical physics methods explain money and income distributions and clarify monetary-economy phenomena from an econophysics perspective
If money is locally conserved in pairwise transactions among agents, the stationary probability distribution of money in statistical equilibrium is exponential (Boltzmann-Gibbs)
Microscopic time-reversal symmetry of transaction rules is sufficient (but conservation alone is not always sufficient) to produce the exponential stationary distribution
When transaction rules are multiplicative or break time-reversal symmetry, distributions become Gamma-like or develop power-law tails instead of pure exponential
Boltzmann kinetic equation and, for small transaction changes, the Fokker-Planck equation are appropriate methods to model time evolution of money distributions and derive stationary forms
Entropy maximization under fixed total money yields the exponential distribution and entropy increases monotonically toward this equilibrium
Empirical income data show a two-class structure: a majority described by exponential (thermal) distribution and a high-income upper class following a power-law (Pareto) tail
Agent-based simulations and analytic solutions confirm exponential stationary money distribution under additive, time-reversible rules and non-exponential outcomes under multiplicative rules
The money temperature equals average money per agent (M/N) and relates to drift and diffusion coefficients in the Fokker-Planck description

Analysis of IRS and Census income data (1983â€“2013) shows lower-class exponential temperature T, an upper-class income fraction f, and Gini coefficient behavior consistent with theory; spikes in f align with market bubbles and quantitative easing
Unified Fokker-Planck models with coexisting additive and multiplicative processes can reproduce the observed two-class income distribution (exponential bulk plus Pareto tail)
Central bank actions (quantitative easing) and bailout flows channel newly created state money primarily to financial institutions and the upper class, increasing income inequality
Empirical temporal correlation: inequality fraction spikes coincide with speculative bubbles and with Fed balance-sheet expansions, implying bailout/monetary policy contributed to inequality growth
Distinction between monetary layer (conserved digital tokens) and physical layer (nonconserved goods/services) is crucial; conflating money and wealth leads to conceptual errors
Wealth (money plus priced goods) can change between transactions via price changes or production, so conservative kinetic models should refer to money rather than wealth to avoid confusion

Debt and lending create promissory layers (strings) distinct from money; peer-to-peer lending and bank lending create debt obligations but do not by themselves increase total money in the closed agent system

Unrestricted debt destabilizes the system: allowing unlimited negative net worth removes boundary conditions, entropy and debt grow without equilibrium, interest accelerates divergence, and crises necessitate state rescues which monetize debt
